quarantines: All overseas arrivals are now required to self isolate for 14 days.
travel_Bans: Borders are entirely closed, except for returning citizens or residents.
schools_closure: All schools and universities closed as of March 16
public_events_cancel: Most events cancelled. Shopping malls closed.
Fiscal_people: People aged 60 and above are dispensed from going to work and cannot face negative consequences as a result. Cost of this is solely born by employers. Government is considering raising conditional cash transfers to protect poor households.
Fiscal_firm: Public banks are lending working capital for companies producing foodstuff, hygienic articles.

quarantines: All overseas arrivals are now required to self isolate for 14 days.
travel_Bans: Cruise ships from foreign ports are banned. Foreign nationals (excluding permanent residents of Australia) who have been in mainland China, Iran, South Korea and Italy will not be allowed to enter Australia for 14 days from the time they have left or transited through the country.
schools_closure: No
public_events_cancel: Organised non-essential public gatherings of more than 500 people are not to occur.
Health: The Government has committed an additional $2.4 billion to support the health system to manage any further outbreak in Australia. The package provides support across primary care, aged care, hospitals and research.
Overall_fiscal_measures: A fiscal stimulus package by the Federal Government totalling A$17.6 billion across the forward estimates has been announced, representing 0.9 per cent of annual GDP. It is anticipated that the government will announce an additional fiscal stimulus package in the coming days. State governments are currently announcing fiscal support packages in addition to the measures of the federal government.
Fiscal_people: As part of the announced fiscal package, the government will provide a one-off $750 payment to social security, veteran and other income support recipients and eligible concession card holders. Around half of those that will benefit are pensioners.
Fiscal_firm: Supports for business investment (i.e. lifting the threshold for assets eligible for a tax write-off and new accelerated depreciation measures) and business cash flows (i.e. payments to SMEs and wage subsidies to such businesses to maintain apprenticeships)
Monetary_Prudential: Cut in the central bank cash rate by 25 basis points (March 3). Further measures to be announced on 19 March.

quarantines: Several areas in Tyrol and Carinthia are under quarantine.
travel_Bans:
Travel restrictions ITA, SVK, CZE, ESP, FRA, CHE
Reintroduction of border controls on its external borders. - Air traffic to be suspended by today (17/03) or tomorrow (18/03).
schools_closure: Since Match 16, all schools and universities are closed
public_events_cancel: The new "Corona-Law", enacted over the weekend, implies a country-wide curfew. All shops, monuments etc. besides pharmacies, supermarkets and other essential businesses are closed until further notice. Austrians are only allowed to leave the house (i) to buy food, (ii) go to work (teleworking is heavily encouraged), (iii) or assist relatives.
Overall_fiscal_measures: The new "Corona-Law" entails fiscal stimulus totalling EUR 4 Billion (1% of GDP) for 2020. THe fiscal stimulus comprises (i) short-time working, (ii) and credit guarantees to ensure liquidity of firms of all sizes. EUR 50 Million habe been put aside to help SMEs in cases of "special hardship". In addition to these measures, the Austrian Ministry of Finance allows to defer taxes and social security contributions without charging interest rates.
Fiscal_people: The government put aside EUR 400 Million (0.1% of GDP) to finance short-time working. Hours worked can be reduced by 10-90%, in some cases even to 0%. The salary loss will be cross-financed by the Public Employment Service Austria (AMS) to up to 80-90% of the original salary. Leave days from last year and any working-time accounts have to be depleted before tapping the short-time working compensation scheme. A comparison: During the GFC, Austria already had a short-time working compensation scheme. Total spending on short-time working in 2009 was EUR 113 Mio.. 66,000 workers have benefitted from it.
Fiscal_firm: EUR 4 billion (minus EUR 400 million for short-time working) have been put aside for credit guarantees for Austrian corporates across all firm sizes. Additional EUR 40 Million are reserved for SMEs in hardship cases. The Ministry of Finance allows for deferals of tax payments and social security contributions without charging interest rates.
Monetary_Prudential: In addition to the EUR 4 Billion package, the OeNB (through the OeKB) grants credit guarantees of EUR 2 Billion (0.5% of GDP) for Austrian enterprises.

schools_closure: Schools remain open, but classes and school activities are interrupted. (Schools take care of children, organised by internal staff, whose parents work in the care sector or essential public services or have no other care solution than their grandparents.)
public_events_cancel: Food stores and pharmacie can remain open suring the week and weekends. Bank counters are open during the week. Other shops remain open during the week but must close during the weekend. All events, both indoor and outdoor and regardless of the size of the public, are canceled until April 3 inclusive.
Fiscal_people: Reduction of working hours
Fiscal_firm: Support for SMEs: suspension of penalties for payment delays on government contracts, provisiong of support to find new markets. The federal government announced exemptions of SSC for the self-employed and the option to put employees on temporary unemployment. In Flanders, businesses, such as bars and restaurants that will be forced to close or that will see their opening hours restricted, will be able to claim a “nuisance grant”  of up to 4 000 euros. The Flemish Government is also standing as guarantor to 100 million euros for loans taken out by businesses and the self-employed.

quarantines: Overseas arrivals from high-risk countries required to self-isolate for 14 days.
travel_Bans: No entry into Bulgaria for people from China, Iran, Bangladesh, India, Maldives, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Spain, Italy, South Korea, France, Germany, Netherlands, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. Bulgarian citizen and permanent residents and their families are exempt.
schools_closure: Nurseries, kindergartens, schools and universities closed. Initially, these measures to remain in place until March 29.
public_events_cancel: Shops, restaurants, amusement/gambling halls, bars and nightclubs shut. Banks, insurance offices, grocery stores and pharmacies remain open. Mass events stopped and sports, cultural and entertainment premises (cinemas, theatres, concerts, museums, conferences, symposia, sports centres, gyms, etc.) are to be closed. All employers, if possible, are to introduce remote work for their employees.
Health: Routine medical consultations, examinations, immunizations, planned operations, and visits to all medical establishments have been stopped. Visits to nursing homes no longer allowed.
Overall_fiscal_measures: No specific measures yet have been announced by the government to support the private sector through the March shutdown. The government estimates that public revenues for 2020 could be 3 billion levs (Eur 1.5 billion or about 2.5% of GDP) less than planned and indicated that a budget update is likely given also the need to increase health spending.
Fiscal_people: Doctors and nurses working in the frontline will receive an additional payment of 1000 leva a month (Eur 500) (large incentive equal to 100% of average per capital household income in 2018).

available_ICU: In many Brazilian states, the public system on which 60 of Brazilians depend does not have any ICUs at all.
travel_Bans: No travel restrictions at this point, although some flight cancellations due to travel bans imposed by other countries.
schools_closure: Schools remain open
public_events_cancel: Local authorities have cancelled many large events.
Health: An additional USD 2 billion have been assigned to the public healthcare system. Taxes and import duties on goods used by hospitals have been zeroed.
Overall_fiscal_measures: A USD 30 billion emergency package has been passed. The government is trying to accelerate the approval of a fiscal reform package that would allow emergency spending. The treasury is considering changes to the fiscal target.
Fiscal_people: The fiscal package includes an additional USD 600 million for conditional cash transfers to accomodate up to 1 million of additional beneficiaries, anticipated disbursement of social transfers, and allows withdrawals from individual unemployment insurance accounts.
Fiscal_firm: Tax liabilities have been deferred for firms, especially SMEs. In addition, administrative procedures for some imports and for loan renegotiations have been eased.
Monetary_Prudential: The requirement for the countercyclical capital buffer in banks has been lowered from 2.5% to 1.25% to allow banks to concede more loans.

quarantines: No massed lockdowns as yet. Increasing number of provinces are announcing states of emergency.
travel_Bans: 18 March. Tighter international travel restrictions introduced, including agreement with U.S. to ban all but essential border traffic.
schools_closure: School closures are close-to nationwide
public_events_cancel: Cancelations widespread across provinces and territories
Health: 12 March package of meassures includes a boost to medical research funding and increase health spending transfers to provinces and territories.
Overall_fiscal_measures:
March 12. Federal government announced an initial package of economic measures (quoted value, CAN 1.1 billion) that include improved insurance sickness benefits , additional funding for health care.
March 18. Federal government package announced (quoted value CAN 27 billion in spending measures and CAN 55 billion in tax deferrals) financial assistance to households and businesses
Note. Federal government fiscal package value detailed here (government numbers): https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse/government-canada-takes-action-covid-19.html
Fiscal_people:
March 12. package of measures includes improved insurance sickness benefits for quarantined workers (one measure being to waive the one-week benefit waiting period). March 18 package of measures includes:
  • immediate financial assistance to those losing their jobs because of business closure, including self-employed and part-time workers unable to collect regular employment-insurance benefits.
  • Delayed tax filings, individuals will not have to file their tax returns until June 1 and can defer any payments until after August 31.
  • Temporarily boost to the Canada Child Benefit.
  • Boost to the GST credit (refundable) that targets lower income houseolds. Every adult who qualifies will receive up to $300 with $150 for every child.
  • Six-month moratorium on repayment of student loans.
  • Doubling of the Reaching Home Program that provides funding for the homeless
  • Establishment of a fund to help Indigenous communities.
Fiscal_firm:
March 13. Federal government announces extra CAN 10 billion in credit to business
March 18 package: Small-business owners to receive a temporary wage subsidy equal to 10 per cent of salary bill for a period of three months.
Monetary_Prudential:
March 4 The Bank of Canada lowered the policy rate by 50 basis points to 1.25%
March 13 Bank of Canada lowers policy rate by 50 basis points to 0.75% (following a rate cut the previous week).
March 16 Bank of Canada announces a range of measures, for instance a broadened range of collateral for its term repo facility https://www.bankofcanada.ca/2020/03/market-notice-2020-03-16/
March 17 Six largest retail banks announce mortgage-payment deferment facilities.
March 18 Bank of Canada urges retailers to continue accepting cash as means of payment

travel_Bans: Controls are introduced at all borders
schools_closure: Schools will  be closed nationwide until April 19.
public_events_cancel: Closure of public establishments and non-essential businesses, public and private events prohibited, closure of places such as restaurants and bars. Public or private events or gatherings with over 100 people are banned.
Health: Hospitals and clinics must stay open but only for necessary procedures.
Fiscal_people: The administrative procedures to apply for part-time unemployment benefit have been eased at short notice.
Fiscal_firm: A priority of the swiss government is to ensure that employees continue to receive their wages. The government is making available a CHF10 billion ($10.6 billion) aid package aimed at helping companies survive the economic downturn caused by coronavirus. Most of the money (CHF8 billion) is earmarked to fund the imposition of short-time work at firms while other tranches have been set aside for hardship loans and to support specific sectors such as event management

quarantines: People from China, Italy and Spain
travel_Bans: Borders will close the 18th indefinitly
schools_closure: Schools plus 26 of the 28 universities will be close for at least two weeks
public_events_cancel: Events of more than 500 people are banned. This could have implications for upcoming protests

available_ICU: 3.6 per 100,000 as of 2017, source from forbes (see link in note)
quarantines:
Strict quarantines, particularly in Wuhan (11 million people) and in over 80 cities in Hubei and other provinces (N.b. such quarantines are quite different from the recent style in some European countries as they also involve a curfew, i.e. confining people to their residences not just to their city).
In Beijing, residents returning from other cities or abroad have been asked to self-quarantine for 14 days. The mesures differ by province/city, many are mandating quarantine for arrivals from abroad. People need to foot the bill for that.
"Social distancing" measures.
travel_Bans: Screening of all passengers, stricter for those arriving from infected places, questionnaires done on board of airplanes
schools_closure: Closure of schools and universities. As of March 16, several cities, not so much affected, have restarted school.
public_events_cancel: Cancellation of public events, the extent of stringency varies by city. In Beijing, for instance, dining in a restaurant for over 2 people is prohibited.
Health:
Medical workers and others participating in the fight against the virus are exempt of personal income tax on their overtime pay/benefits and in-kind payment is not included in their salaries
Medical equipment and pharmaceuticals related to the new coronavirus are exempt from registration fees - Public procurement commitment for extra installed capacity of masks and other prevention materials in case market demand shrinks
Specific corporate income tax (CIT) incentives introduced for enterprises engaged in producing key supplies related to coronavirus protection and containment (e.g. masks, protective clothing). This includes a 100% expensing deduction for investment in equipment to expand production capacity.
Support to vaccine and medicine-related research to fight the virus
STA encourages local tax authorities and taxpayers to deal with tax matters remotely, such as via e-tax bureaus, mobile applications, etc - Building 2 new hospitals (by now dismantled) and dozens of laboratories for testing
Overall_fiscal_measures: Frontloading of infrastructure projects, launching of new projects locally, those not yet approved, however
Fiscal_people:
Exemption for small-scaled taxpayers in Hubei province and reduced the VAT collection rate to 1% (currently 3%) for small-scaled taxpayers in other areas, from March 1 to May 31 2020.
Exemption of a wide range of consumer services from VAT on a nationwide basis. So-called ‘lifestyle services’, which include medical services, catering and accommodation services, and sundry personal services (e.g. hairdressing, laundry) are normally subject to VAT at 6%. The VAT exemption also applies to public transportation and express delivery services provided to residents. The exemption is not time limited; it is understood to be in place until the coronavirus is brought under control.
Fiscal_firm:
Accommodation and catering SMEs exempt from social security contributions
Large firms required to pay only half of social security contributions
Firms in accommodation/catering and personal services exempt from VAT
Firms in the 4 industries of transport, catering, accommodation and tourism are allowed to carry forward their 2020 losses for up to 8 years
Full refund of carried forward excess input VAT balances may be granted to enterprises engaged in production of supplies for coronavirus protection and containment. The refundable input VAT amount is the accumulated carried forward input VAT balance, to the extent it exceeds the carried forward input VAT balance as at the end of December 2019. Refund applications may be made monthly.
Airlines exempt from contribution to the airline development fund.
Extension of statutory tax filing to February 28. This can be further extended by local tax authorities where the outbreak is particularly serious (such as in Hubei province).
Monetary_Prudential:
1 and 5-year benchmark rate lowered by 10bp
China Development Bank issued the first batch of special bonds to fight the virus, equivalent of CNY 135 billion at 1.65% for the purpose of emergency funding for affected firms - From March 16, the reserve requirement ratio will be reduced in a targeted way, for two types of banks: 50-100 bp for banks meeting criteria of lending shares to SMEs, agriculture and entrepreneurs and 100 bp for selected joint-stock banks. Banks meeting both sets of criteria can cumulate the cuts. Emphasis on access to loans recently, not just rolling over as most SMEs did not have loans in the first place.

travel_Bans: All borders with Venezuela are closed, and no foreigners are allowed to enter the country, and only those with a migrant visa, a courtesy visa, and diplomats will be able to do so; they also have to do 14 days of quarentine.
schools_closure: All primary, secondary schools and higher education institutions will be closed from Monday  16 March for two weeks.
public_events_cancel: mass events should be limited to a maximum of 50 people; the closure of bars and clubs throughout the country.
Fiscal_people: All children receiving family subsidies for poverty alleviation will received a food basket at home, comparable to what they received during school.
Fiscal_firm: Postponement of the payment of the VAT and income taxes for the tourism and aviation sectors. Reduction of the import tariffs for some inputs related to the health and aviation sectors, on a temporary basis. New credit line (COL 250 000 millions) for the tourism and aviation sector. Reduction of gasoline price.
Monetary_Prudential: Increased quotas of the daily auctions to increase liquidity in the market

quarantines: State of emergency was declared 16th March.
travel_Bans: From 18 March and until 13th April, only Costa Ricans and residents in Costa Rica will be able to enter the country.
schools_closure: School and universities are closed until 13th April (conditional cash transfers are maintained)
public_events_cancel:
Restaurants, bars and cinemas should operate at 50% of capacity.
Easter week activities have been cancelled.
Overall_fiscal_measures: Public banks will be asked to readjust loans, including a possible moratorium on the payment of principal and / or interest for three extendable months, particularly for the most affected sectors.
Fiscal_people: Collection of social security contributions for the time actually worked, in addition to deferring the payment of social security contributions. This measure will need to be approved by the Social Security Board of Directors, given the institution's autonomy.
Fiscal_firm:
Three-month moratorium on the payment of Value Added Tax, Income Tax and customs duties, all for formally constituted companies. This measure would need to be approved by Congress through a law.
A preferential rate for occupational risk insurance for companies with less than 30 workers (announced/not yet implemented).
Authorizing a new product to help the tourism sector face the contingencies caused by COVID-19. It is a quarantine insurance for tourists who come to the country.
Monetary_Prudential:
The Central Bank reduced the monetary policy rate by 100 basis points to 1.25% on 16th March.
Temporary adjustments to prudential regulations to create space for the re-adjustment of credits. In particular, it becomes possible to renegotiate twice in a 24-month period the agreed conditions of loans, without these being considered a special operation and having negative effects on the risk rating of debtors.
Temporary reduction of countercyclical provisions by banks

quarantines:
From 16 to 24 March the free movement of people within the country is banned, with some exceptions (travel to work, medical facilities, family and other necessary trips). All foreigners without residence are prohibited from entering the country and citizens and foreigners with a residence are prohibited from leaving the country.
On March 12, the Government declared a state of emergency for 30 days.
travel_Bans:
As of 13 March 2020, the mandatory 14-day quarantine after returning from abroad applies to 15 countries.
Flights from South Korea and northern Italy are cancelled since 5 March.
schools_closure: All primary, secondary schools and higher education institutions will be closed from Wednesday 11 March until further notice.
public_events_cancel: From 14 March 2020 to 24 March 2020, all stores are closed except for grocery stores, pharmacies, sellers of sanitary goods, medical devices and fuels and sales via the Internet and other remote stores.
Health:
From 16 March 2020, the government has banned all doctors, dentists, pharmacists and medical staff from taking their leave during the emergency.
All public authorities and administrations instructed to switch to limited operations until 24 March.
The Ministry of Finance announced on March 4 that it would start regulating prices of protective respiratory masks (FFP3 class) and prohibited exporting the masks and their sale to the general public.
Overall_fiscal_measures: COVID Loan programme fos SMEs of CZK 1.6bn (59m EUR) – see more details under SMEs policies
Fiscal_firm: Support for SMEs: From the COVID loan program SMEs will be able to apply for an interest-free loan in the range of CZK 0.5 to 15m with a one-year moratorium on repayments. These loans will be available from April 1st, to firms that can demonstrate that they have been economically affected by the coronavirus.
Monetary_Prudential:
On 16 March 2020, the Czech National Bank cut the main policy rate by 50 basis points, to 1.75%.
The Board declared that it was ready to cut interest rates further should this be warranted by economic developments. It announced that it stood ready to intervene in the foreign exchange market to prevent excessive volatility of the koruna (in line with the managed float).
While the Board does not detect a shortage of liquidity in the banking sector, it will from now on conduct its liquidity-providing repo operations three times a week instead of once a week, with no spread over the policy rate (previously 10bps).
The Board also revised its earlier decision to increase the countercyclical capital buffer rate to 2% with effect from 1 July 2020. This step will now not happen, and banks will continue to maintain the current buffer at 1.75%. The Board will closely observe the situation, and stands ready to reduce the buffer to 0%, if deemed necessary

travel_Bans: Borders to France, Luxembourg, Switzerland and Austria have been closed on Monday, 16 March. Goods and commuters are allowed to cross border.
schools_closure: Most schools and day care centres closed
public_events_cancel: - Closure of all non-essential shops, sport clubs, bars, night clubs, theatres and playgrounds. Restaurants will need to close at 6pm.
Health: - The budget committee provided additional € 800 million for protective equipment, equipment for intensive care and research on vaccines. Previously, around € 350 billion were already agreed on for protective equipment and the WHO. - Total fiscal cost: € 1.14 billion
Overall_fiscal_measures: - Coalition parties agreed on an additional investment package of € 3.1 billion per year over the period 2021 – 2024 funded by the 2019 budget surplus.
Fiscal_firm: - Short-time working schemes: The “short-time” work scheme will be easier to access temporarily as was the case during the financial crisis. Firms will be able to request support for their workers under this scheme if 10% of their workforce are affected by cuts in working hours as opposed to one third under the usual regulation. In addition to compensating 60% of the difference in monthly net earnings due to reduced hours, the labour agency will now also cover 100% of social-security contributions for the lost work hours. This is an increase compared to the financial crisis, where only 50% of social-security contributions were subsidised and employers had to cover the other half. Firms have already started to use “short-time” work more frequently over the past few months in response to the industrial downturn.  - The government announced it will provide all liquidity support needed to companies mostly through new and existing programs with the KfW. Credits will not be limited. Firm size limitations for liquidity support will also be adjusted upwards and the risk taken by the government will be increased. The volume of guarantees provided by guarantee banks will be doubled to €2.5 billion. Also, banks will be able to decide on guarantees more quickly. In addition, tax deferrals will be possible.

travel_Bans:
Borders are closed to non-citizens with no critical reason to visit (e.g. work or sick family member).
Air traffic de facto shut down.
Restrictions have been imposed on the number of passengers in public transport and capacity has been increased.
schools_closure: All schools, childcare and education facilities are closed until 30 March.
public_events_cancel:
Indoor events with more than 100 participants are banned.
Sport clubs, bars, night clubs etc. are strongly encouraged to close for the time being
Health:
The health sector postpones treatment of all non-critical issues.
Legislation will be passed to allow the health sector to focus on critically ill people only and use forced isolation and forced vaccination if needed.
Overall_fiscal_measures:
A tripartite agreement on wage subsidies was reached with social partners on 15 March. For firms experiencing large falls in demand, the employees can be send home and the government will cover 75% of the salary (maximum EUR 3 100), if the firm promises not to lay off any workers for economic reasons. Firms will also have to cover the remaining 25% to ensure employees can keep their full salary. For hourly workers (with no notice period) the compensation rate is 90% (maximum EUR 3500). The scheme is so far available for three months (expected fiscal costs DKK 2.7 billion).
A short-time work scheme is available and has been made more flexible and allocated more resources (less than DKK 100 million).
Fiscal_firm:
Sick leave benefits for people with COVID-19 will be fully covered by the government. Normally, employers pay the first 30 days of sick leave and self-employed have a two-week waiting period. Both are suspended (DKK 1.7 billion).
Two loan guarantee schemes. One for large firms (market-based) and one for SMEs (DKK 1 billion resources reserved for expected losses).
Compensation to organisers of events that are cancelled due to the ban on large public gatherings (DKK 100 million).
VAT and tax payments have been deferred and is expected to boost liquidity by DKK 165 billion in total, of which DKK 40 billion are targeted SMEs.
Monetary_Prudential:
The full countercyclical capital buffer has been released.
The Central Bank has launched an extraordinary lending facility to ensure the banking sector has access to liquidity at favourable terms.

quarantines: Mandated nation-wide quarantine for at least 15 days since Monday 16, March
travel_Bans: Direct flights from Italy are cancelled
schools_closure: Closure of schools nationwide.
public_events_cancel:
All premises and establishments that carry out public-facing activity are closed, apart from those distributing foodstuffs and essential items.
Cafés and restaurants are shut, but they will be able to deliver food to people’s homes.
Public shows such as cinemas and theaters are closed, as well as sporting events, museums, etc.
All local fiestas and marches are suspended.
Health: 2.8 billion euros to the autonomous communities to strengthen health services and mobilise from the contingency fund an additional 1 billion euros for the Ministry of Health.
Overall_fiscal_measures: Additional measures willl be announced on March 17th.
Fiscal_people: Support to families in vulnerable positions: 25 million euros to provide food to children affected by school closures to combat child poverty.  Extension of social Security bonuses in discontinuous fixed contracts to cover contracts from February to June 2020 in the tourism sector, in order to preserve employment.
Fiscal_firm:
Support for tourism: Secretary of State for Tourism is preparing a series of extra measures across all ministries (package)
Six month moratorium on taxes for SMEs and self-employed, which is estimated to inject 14 billion euros in liquidity to the economy.
400 million euro credit line to most affected sectors such as tourism and transport.
Companies that have received loans from the General Secretariat for Industry and Small and Medium Enterprises are allowed to postpone their repayment.

travel_Bans: The Commission proposed to restrict non-essential travel to the European Union for an initial period of 30 days, with exceptions mainly for EU and British citizens, long-time residents, cross-border commuters, health care workers and workers delivering goods
public_events_cancel: A ban on events with more than 500 attendees until 31 May.
Health: The Commission is taking stock of available equipment and of production and distribution capacity, and will pursue joint public procurements. Tensions have emerged as some member states have imposed tighter rules on exports of these supplies, potentially undermining the internal market.
Overall_fiscal_measures:
Proposal “Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative” includes:
  • Member States will not have to pay back to the EU budget unspent pre-financing received from structural funds, worth about EUR 8 billion. Instead, they will be able to use this money as national co-financing for the next tranches of their structural fund allocations (worth about EUR 29 bn, totalling EUR 37 bn).
  • Enlarged eligibility provisions comprise investment for public health services and some financing of working capital in SMEs.
  • Cohesion policy total country allocations for the 2014-2020 period remain unchanged; there is no “new money” involved.
  • Flexibility in EC budget rules: When assessing compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact, the Commission will take account of the temporary nature of some COVID-19-related fiscal measures (“one-offs”) and of the outbreak being an unusual event outside the control of government. The required fiscal adjustment will take account of cyclical developments.
  • The general escape clause mat be activated in case of a severe economic downturn for the euro area or EU as a whole.

Other proposals by the EC:
  • Extending the scope of the EU Solidarity Fund to cover major public health emergencies and to increase advance payments from this Fund (up to EUR 800 million available in 2020)
  • Using the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support dismissed workers and those self-employed (up to EUR 179 million available in 2020)
  • Providing EUR 1 billion from the EU budget as a guarantee to the European Investment Fund (part of the EIB group) to support SME financing.
Fiscal_firm: The EC vowed to help member states ramp up their response by permitting aid for struggling businesses. In particular, the Commission considers that the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy is causing a serious disturbance to the economy (Article 107(3)(b) of the Treaty), which enables the Commission to approve additional national support measures.
Monetary_Prudential:
On 12 March 2020 the ECB decided to ease financial conditions further:
  • In TLTRO III operations, considerably more favourable terms will be applied during the period from June 2020 to June 2021. These operations will support bank lending to those affected most by the spread of the coronavirus, particularly SMEs. Throughout this period, the interest rate on these TLTRO III operations will be 25 basis points below the average rate applied in the Eurosystem’s main refinancing operations.
  • Additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) will be conducted, temporarily, to provide immediate liquidity support to the euro area financial system. They will be carried out through a fixed rate tender procedure with full allotment, with an interest rate that is equal to the average rate on the deposit facility (-0.50%).
  • A temporary envelope of additional net asset purchases of €120 billion to be added until the end of the year, ensuring a strong contribution from the private sector purchase programmes.
  • On the supervisory front, the ECB will allow banks to operate temporarily below the level of capital defined by the Pillar 2 Guidance (P2G), the capital conservation buffer (CCB) and the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR). The ECB considers that these temporary measures will be enhanced by the appropriate relaxation of the countercyclical capital buffer (CCyB) by the national macroprudential authorities.

quarantines:
The Finnish government declared a state of emergency. As of 18 March, stringent containment measures will apply at the national level for one month.
Visiting elderly homes as well as care homes is forbidden.
The limitations will not apply to the necessary functioning of the society. People can still go to the grocery store and the pharmacy.
travel_Bans: The closure of borders is being prepared. Finnish residents should not travel abroad, and residents currently abroad should return. Those returning will undertake a mandatory two-week quarantine.
schools_closure: As of 18 March, schools and universities are shut down as of March 18. This does not apply to nurseries and day-care centres, but the parents are advised to keep their children at home.
public_events_cancel:
As of 18 March, some public services (e.g. museums) will be closed. Non-public sector service providers are encouraged to follow suit.
Public gatherings of more than 10 people are banned.
Health:
Set up of a coordination group to fight the coronavirus outbreak
Expenditure of initial € 9 million euros in preparations to contain it.
Overall_fiscal_measures: A 5 billion euros (2% of GDP) stimulus package will be launched. This is to provide credit to businesses, ensure liquidity in the financial sector, and provide extra spending on healthcare.

quarantines: As of 17 March (at noon), stringent containment measures to slow the epidemics have been implemented. The confinement measures will apply at the national level for at least two weeks. They include a ban on non-essential and non-certified meetings and outings from homes, as well as strengthened enforcement of the new rules through fines.
travel_Bans: Travel within towns, between regions and outside the country have been severly limited (need for a good reason and steep reduction of transport offers)
schools_closure: Day-care services, schools and universities are closed until further notice.
public_events_cancel: Public meetings have been banned. Non-essential shops are closed. Teleworking is strongly encouraged. Many firms have stopped.
Health:
Unlocked EUR 265 million (from unused 2019 credits) and put forward the 2020 payments to hospitals,
Uncapped overtime in the hospital sector,
Reduced regulatory barriers to the use of telemedicine, such as easing restrictions on reimbursement of consultations done by telephone or videoconference, which currently limit its use
The authorities are moving on a case-by-case basis to the collection of sample tests at home, the use of ambulatory care for some COVID-19 patients and home confinements.
Allowed pharmacists to make their hydro alcoholic solutions and regulated their prices, as well as overtook the national stock and production of protective masks.
Armed forces will intervene to move sick people and build bed capacity in Alsace.
Overall_fiscal_measures: - Joint actions/coordination: joint actions are being taken between national and regional authorities to manage the crisis as part of the new Economic Council ‘Etats-Régions’, including to set-up regional Task Forces together with development banks (BPI), to accelerate support measures for businesses enterprises.  - The costs of the fiscal package for households and firms, as well as the healthcare sector, are officially estimated (as of March 17) at around EUR 45 billion, ie 1.9% of 2019 GDP. This estimate is based on the assumption of extensive use of short-term work schemes by 1.5 million employees for 2.5 months. The main fiscal costs are the postponement of social and fiscal deadlines (EUR 32 billion) ; the short-time work scheme (EUR 8.5 billion), health measures (EUR 2 billion); the solidarity fund (EUR 1 billion); and the potential liabilities linked to public guarantees (EUR 0.5 billion).
Fiscal_people: - Increased sick leave reimbursements for affected workers, as well as those facing school closures. - Short-term work schemes will help maintain household income despite partial business closures (see also firm-specific measures). - A "solidarity fund" will support income for the self-employed and entrepreneurs (see also firm-specific measures).
Fiscal_firm: Broad-based support measures for the most affected firms. Including:  - postponing the payments of social security contributions and taxes, and a on case-by-case basis granting exemptions - providing guaranteed treasury loans (up to 90% for SMEs and larger firms), the public guarantees are up to EUR 300 billion (12.4% of GDP)    - encouraging conflict mediation between SMEs and clients/suppliers - encouraging the use of short-time work schemes (by shortening procedures and a higher public coverage of firms’ costs). The government has also allowed companies to declare the epidemic as a cause of “force majeure” if it prevented them fulfilling their public procurement contracts.                                                                                                               - strengthening the short-time work scheme for employees by making it retroactive from the application. The take up of short-time work schemes has reached 900 firms and 15,000 employees (on 6 March).                                                                                                          - setting-up a “solidarity fund” for self-employed workers to cover up to 80% of their net income.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         - Suspension of water and energy bills as well as rents for the smallest firms.

quarantines: 14-day isolation for households with symptoms
Health:
NSH can have however many 'millions or billions' it requires to tackle the illness
Raise health workforce supply by recalling retired doctors and delaying non-urgent and elective care (although not a successful measure)
Overall_fiscal_measures:
On 11 March announced a GBP 30 billion stimulus package, including 12 bn to counter the impacts of the outbreak. The 2020 budget represents the largest sustained fiscal loosening since 1992.
The fiscal package of 12bn to fight the coronavirus includes a 5 bn emergency response fund for the National health Service (NHS) and 7 bn business support.
Fiscal_people: Statutory sick pay will be available to all those advised to self-isolate
Fiscal_firm:
- In the case of covid-19 moving to fourth phase (mitigation), businesses struggling to pay their liabilities will use the “Time To Pay” system operated by HM Revenue & Customs. This enables the business to pay everything that it owes through a payment plan.
The government will refund the cost of statutory sick pay to businesses for up to 14 days at a cost of 2bn pounds
loan guarantee scheme for banks lending to small businesses on amounts of up to £1.2m
Business rates will also be scrapped for the next year for hospitality companies, venue owners, galleries and cinemas with a rateable value of up to £51,000. All smaller businesses that pay no business rates will receive a £3,000 cash grant, worth a total of £3bn
Other tax measures included a 90 per cent cut in entrepreneurs’ tax relief, which will raise £3bn a year
On 11 March the government announced that 7bn from the emergency budget will be dedicated to support affected businesses: ‒ a temporary loan schemes for small business with measures including:
statutory sick pay for self-quarantined people
a refund of the cost of statutory sick leave up to 2 weeks for small businesses
and a freeze of business rates on property for heavily hit sectors in 2020, including retail, hospitality and entertainment
Monetary_Prudential:
On 11 March BoE cut rate to 0.25%
BoE offering banks four years of cheap funding to they could continue to lend
Capital buffer requirements loosened to allow banks to take temporary loses without curtailing lending
the Prudential Regulation Authority set out expectations that banks should not increase dividends or bonuses in response to the BoE's policy actions

quarantines: 14-day home restriction on anyone entering Greece
travel_Bans: Air links to Spain, passanger travel to Italy, Albania and Northern Macedonia suspended except for Greek nationals. Cruise and tourist ships banned.
schools_closure: In place.
public_events_cancel: Restaurants, coffee shops, hair salons, malls and beaches and resorts closed from Wednesday. Olympic-related events cancelled. Tourism effectively shut down.
Health: EUR 200 m for health system, EUR 75 for hiring 2000 health workers. 950 already hired.
Fiscal_people: Financial and social-security handouts to employees who need to stop working or take a leave of absence.
Fiscal_firm: Facilitate public and private sectors employees to work different hours, or from home; with additional costs to be shared by businesses and the state. Businesses which are obliged to shut down will not have to pay any taxes or national insurance contributions

quarantines: 122 people in quarantine
travel_Bans: Borders are closed, except for returning citizens or residents. Moreover, transit is still permitted.
schools_closure: In place for all education institutions.
public_events_cancel: A ban on hospital visits in all inpatient health and social institutions. Indoor sport events may max include 100 people, while the limit on outdoor events is 500 people. Entertainment  facilities are closed, while restaurants and cafeterias may remain open until 3 pm. Shops are closed with the exception of food retail, pharmacies and other essential products.
Health: The government has released some additional funding to the health sector. All hospital vists are banned.
Overall_fiscal_measures: No active fiscal measures to offset the economic impact have been announced.
Monetary_Prudential: The National Bank of Hungary recommends commercial banks to implement a loan repayment moratorium and has implemented it on its SME loans under the Financing Growth Scheme.

travel_Bans: Visa exemption policy is suspended for at least one month; visa will be provided upon the delivery of a health certificate. Restrictions are in place for travelers having visited in the last 14 days China, Iran, Italy, the Vatican, Spain, France, Germany, South Korea, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.
Health: 17.2 trillion rupiah (USD 1.1 bln) of budget reallocated for healthcare (as of 18 March)
Overall_fiscal_measures:
A first IDR 10.3 trillion (USD 725 million) stimulus package was unveiled the week of Monday 24 February to support consumer spending and tourism; however, it seems to consist mainly of reclassification and front-loading of previous spending commitments.
Media report that the government will soon announce eight measures worth more than IDR 10 trillion (USD 720 million).
The government plans to reduce the number of restricted import goods by up to 50 percent
a second fiscal stimulus package was announced on 13 March representing 0.8% of GDP (IDR 120 trillion or about USD 8.1b).
Fiscal_people: Key dispositions of the second fiscal package include exempting some manufacturing workers from income tax
Fiscal_firm: The second fiscal package includes reducing corporate tax payments for manufacturing companies.
Monetary_Prudential:
BI announced on March 9 five measures to stabilize the rupiah – including cutting the USD reserve requirement ratio (RRR) to 4% from 8% and the rupiah RRR by 50 basis points, starting April 1 (only for banks with clients engaged in export and import activities).
BI stepped up interventions to stabilize the rupiah in the domestic non-deliverable forward (DNDF) and spot markets, as well as purchase of government bonds (SBN) on the secondary market.
The BI board of governors will meet on March 18 and 19 to determine the direction of monetary policy going forward.
On March 11, Indonesia's central bank bought more than 8 trillion rupiah (USD550 million) of government bonds from two auctions and the largest SOEs have been authorised to buy back their shares

travel_Bans:
India has suspended all visas, except A few categories such as diplomatic and employment to prevent The spread of The virus. The government also “strongly advised” Indians to avoid all non-essential travel abroad.
Some companies ask employees to work from home temporarily.
schools_closure: Schools have been closed in some municipalities (including Delhi from March 5th).
public_events_cancel: In some states or cities, partial shutdowns have been imposed. Educational institutions, stadiums, cinema halls, and sports clubs are closed in some cities  -- Delhi decided today to ban gathering of more than 50 people at a place as part of its efforts to combat the rapidly-spreading coronavirus, including all social, political, cultural, religious and family events.
Health:
The press suggests that therapy trials are going on, including a combination of the two anti-HIV drugs, with success on some patients (https://www.livemint.com/news/india/rajsthan-official-says-anti-hiv-drugs-proved-crucial-in-coronavirus-treatment-11584357100438.html). The Drug Controller General of India has granted approval to the Indian Council of Medical Research to use a combination of 2 drugs (lopinavir and ritonavir) already approved (for the treatment of HIV) in the event of the coronavirus disease in India turns into a public health emergency.
In March, the government introduced export restrictions for 26 pharma products (active pharma ingredients and formulations, including paracetamol) to keep domestic supplies steady. This measure is likely to be maintained until raw material imports from China resume.
Overall_fiscal_measures: No significant fiscal package has been announced so far at the central government level. Some social and economic measures are being taken at the state level.
Fiscal_people: No significant fiscal package has been announced so far at the central government level. Some social and economic measures are being taken at the state level. As an example, the state government of Bihar announced today it will bear the entire expenses incurred on the treatment of the coronavirus patients. The Chief Minister of Bihar also announced a compensation for family in the case of death due to coronavirus.
Monetary_Prudential: The governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) today stated that it will take all necessary measures to reduce the economic impact of the covid-19, including: i)o a second USD/INR sell/buy swap auction to provide liquidity to the foreign exchange market for March 23rd (a first auction took place today) https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_PressReleaseDisplay.aspx?prid=49501; ii) it will conduct additional Long Term Repo Operations (LTROs) for a total of INR 1 trillion at the policy repo rate (5.15%) to improve monetary policy transmission. https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_PressReleaseDisplay.aspx?prid=49524; iii) o It publicises e-commerce and the availability of digital payment options to avoid social contact and visit to public places.

travel_Bans: Italy is the only country on the "do not travel" list for travel advice
schools_closure: Yes (since March 12)
public_events_cancel: The government has advised that indoor mass gatherings of 100 people or more and outdoor mass gatherings of more than 500 people should be cancelled all State-run cultural institutions have closed, as have pubs.
Health:
Funds set aside for increased illness benefits: EUR 2.4 bn
Extra funding for treatment of affected populaation: EUR 435 million Some hospitals have started to ban visitors. Over 60 staff at Cork University Hospital have been asked to self-isolate following coronavirus case that resulted from community transmission.
Overall_fiscal_measures: eur 3 billion stimulus package (around 1% of GDP)
Fiscal_people: A package of sick pay and illness/supplementary benefits to ensure that employees and the self-employed can abide by medical advice to self-isolate where appropriate, while having their income better protected than under current social welfare rules. This is estimated to cost up to €2.4 billion.
Fiscal_firm: Initial support for liquidity of impacted firms: EUR 200 million

quarantines: voluntary quarantines
travel_Bans: No official social distancing measures or limitations or bans on public gatherings are in effec
schools_closure: Since 12 March secondry schools and universities are closed for four weeks. Primary and pre-school remain open
Overall_fiscal_measures: Tax payments for affected firms are postponed. Credit lines may be extended
Monetary_Prudential: Key policy rate lowered from 2.75% to 2.25 on March 11. Minimum reserve requirements redcued from 1% to 0%.

quarantines: As of 9 March all Israelis returning from abroad are ordered into a 14-day quarantine. This measure will be in effect for two weeks initially.
travel_Bans: Since12 March all non-Israelis will be barred completely from entering Israel unless they can demonstrate that they have a place to self-isolate in Israel for 14 days. This extends previous measures that were confined to travellers from most affected countries in Asia and Europe.
schools_closure: All educational institutions are closed including pre-schools and kindergartens
public_events_cancel:
all indoor gatherings exceeding 10 people are barred
all entertainment venues are closed, including shopping malls, cinemas, bars and restaurants
Health: NIS 1 billion allocated to health system
Overall_fiscal_measures:
Overall package of NIS 10 billion (about EUR 2.5 billion) announced on 11 March:
  • NIS 1 billion for health sector
  • NIS 1 billion for special needs (police, fire service etc)
  • Fund for state guaranteed loans of NIS 8 billion to assist mainly SMEs with cash-flow problems (increased from previously 4 billion announced on 10 March)

On March 16 Finance Minister Kahlon announced further support measures :
  • All employees on unpaid leave for at least 30 days will be able to claim unemployment benefits immediately. Unemployment benefits can be claimed after employment for the least 6 months, from 12 months previously
  • A one-time payment of NIS 6000 (about EUR 1500) for the self-employed. Criteria are still to be set.
.
Fiscal_people:
On March 16 Finance Minister Kahlon announced further support measures
  • All employees on unpaid leave for at least 30 days will be able to claim unemployment benefits immediately. Unemployment benefits can be claimed after employment for the least 6 months, from 12 months previously
  • A one-time payment of NIS 6000 (about EUR 1500) for the self-employed. Criteria are still to be set.
Fiscal_firm:
Fund for state guaranteed loans of NIS 8 billion to assist mainly SMEs with cash-flow problems (increased from previously 4 billion announced on 10 March)
VAT, municipal taxes and social security contribution have been deferred for SMEs until the end of April
Monetary_Prudential:
On 15 March BOI announced:
  • start of purchasing government bonds of various types and maturities in the secondary market (undisclosed amount)
  • offer repo transactions to financial institutions with government bonds as collateral to “moderate the abnormal volatility and to increase the liquidity in the financial markets” (undisclosed amount)
  • a list of regulatory leniencies for banks (e.g. leniencies in the repayment of mortgages or loans to SMEs), aimed at preventing a tightening in credit conditions and to support the economy

On 18 March
  • BOI offers one-week US dollar swaps up to NIS 15 billion

quarantines:
Nation-wide quarantine. “I stay at home decree”, aims at limiting the movement and contact of people. People are invited to stay at home but can leave it in case of necessity or justified motives. These include going to work, purchase necessities, assist old relatives
Reconversion of facilities (e.g., army barracks) to host people in quarantine
travel_Bans: Strict travel restrictions nation-wide
schools_closure: Closure of schools and universities until April 3
public_events_cancel:
Bars and restaurants along with many other retail trade activities (e.g. shopping centres; indoor and outdoor markets) will close until the 25th of March. Departments that are not indispensable to production activities should suspend activities.
All sporting competitions are suspended until the same day (along with other public gatherings).
Health:
EUR 1 billion will be injected into the national health service, with the target of recruiting 20 000 more health workers
Ease burden of hospitals: dedicate entire facilities to patients infected with Covid-19, while redirected non-infected patients for other facilities
Increased cleaning of public transportation facilities, such as metro transit, buses, boats
Measures to increase production of medical materials (masks, ventillation machines)
Overall_fiscal_measures:
On the 11th of March the Prime Minister announced that the government is going to request the Parliament the authorization to increase spending in 2020 by up to EUR 25 billion (1.1% of GDP) to deal with the economic fall out of the epidemics. The government does not expect to use the EUR 25 billion in full. The decree with the detailed policy measures (initially for about EUR 12 billion) is expected for Friday 13th of March.
On Tuesday 10 March, Italy increased the fiscal measures from 7.5 to 10bn euros
Extension of deadline to submit tax returns from to Sept. 30 from July 2
Suspension of tax payments (income, wealth, social security contributions, etc.) for 10 Lombardy municipalities (implemented on 21 February)
Fiscal_people:
Parental leave and support for working parents. Proposal of EUR 500 one-off payments to working parents with dependent children.
Wage supplementation scheme (CIG Straordinaria) of EUR 6.5bn
Moratorium on debt payments, including mortgages
Fiscal_firm:
Expansion of resources for the guarantee fund for SMEs, which could allow them to have moratoriums on repaying their bank loans moratorium on debt payments
Announcement of the potential introduction of tax credits for companies that reported a 25% drop in revenues.

quarantines:
Enforced the strengthened immigration control on Monday 9 March, which requires all visitors from China and Korea to be quarantined in designated areas for two weeks.
The Basic Policy launched on 25 February asked people with mild flu-like symptoms to isolate themselves at home and wait four days before contacting a doctor.
The Basic Policy also urged companies to introduce teleworking and staggered commuting.
travel_Bans:
MoFA recommended cancelling all travels to Hubei Province in China (Level 3 warning) on 24 Jan.
MoFA recommended cancelling non-essential travels to all areas in China except Hubei Province (Level 2 warning) on 31 Jan.
MoFA recommended cancelling non-essential travels to Daeg City and Gyeongsanbuk-do Cheongdo County in South Korea (Level 2 warning) on 25 Feb.
MoFA recommended cancelling non-essential travels to Iran (Level 2 warning) on 26 Feb.
MoFA recommended cancelling non-essential travels to North Italy (Lombardia, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna) (Level 2 warning) on 1 March.
MoFA recommended cancelling all travels to Daeg City and Gyeongsanbuk-do Cheongdo County (Level 3 warning) and non-essential travels to all other areas in South Korea (Level 2 warning) on 5 March.
MoFA recommended cancelling all travels to Lombardia in Italy (Level 3 warning) on 6 March.
MoFA recommended cencelling all travels to North Italy (Lombardia, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche and Piemonte), San Marino, and several Provinces in Iran (Alborz, Esfahan, Qazvin, Semnan, Mazandaran, Markazi and Lorestan) (Level 3 warning) and non-essential travels to all other areas in Italy and Vatican City (Level 2 warning) on 9 March.
MoFA recommended cancelling all travels to North Italy (Lombardia, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, Piemonte, Liguria, Trentino Alto Adige, Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Valle d'Aosta), Madrid, Euskal Herria and La Rioja in Spain, Canton Titino in Switzerland, Iceland, San Marino and Vatican City (Level 3 warning) and non-essential travels to all other areas in Europe (Level 2 warning) on 16 March.
schools_closure: On 27 February, the government asked local governments to close all public schools until April.
public_events_cancel:
On 24 February, the government asked large scale events and gatherings to be cancelled for two weeks.
On 10 March, the government asked to extend the voluntary ban on events and gatherings until 19 March.
Health:
On 28 January, the Cabinet issued a decree to list COVID-19 as a disease that the Infectious Disease Act and the Quarantine Act apply. With the decree enforced on 7 February, the authority can order the patients about forced hospitalisation and restrictions on work, mandate immigrations to take laboratory tests, and provide medical care with the costs shouldered by the government.
On 14 February, the government decided the use of the contingent funds included in the FY 2019 budget to fund a package of immediate measures of EUR 128 million, including increasing the testing capacity and production of medical apparatus such as masks and antiseptic solutions.
The Basic Policy launched on 25 February prioritised the provision of medical service to vulnerable people such as the elderly and those who have underlying conditions.
On 13 March, the Diet passed an amendment of the Act on Special Measures Against Novel Influenza and Other Diseases to tentatively include COVID-19 for two years. The law enables the Prime Minister to impose a state of emergency nationwide, which endorses Prefectural Governors’ decisions to restrict economic and social activity such as school closure.
Overall_fiscal_measures:
Following the immediate measures of JPY 15.3 billion (0.003% of GDP) announced on 13 February, the government launced the second package of JPY 270 billion (0.05% of GDP) using the remained contingent funds included in the FY 2019 budget on 10 March.
On 14 March, the Prime Minister expressed his will to formulate an additional fiscal stimulus package. It is expected to follow the passage of the FY 2020 budget, which is under review in the Upper House of the Diet.
Fiscal_people: The second measures launched on 10 March included compensation benefits for workers’ absence due to temporary closure of their workplaces or their children’s schools.
Fiscal_firm:
The first prompt measures announced on 14 February included JPY 500 billion (0.1% of GDP) of emergency loans and debt guarantees for the tourism industry.
The second measures launched on 10 March included unsecured interest-free loans to affected firms.
Monetary_Prudential:
On 9 March, the Bank of Japan announced last Monday that the Bank makes its best effort in providing abundant liquidity and maintaining the stability of the financial market, including a fixed-term JGB purchase of JPY 500 billion (0.1% of GDP).
On 16 March, the BoJ decided to strengthen monetary easing through three measures:
  • Accelerating the ETF and J-REIT purchases, which has been kept at the annual pace of JPY 6 trillion yen (1.1% of GDP) and JPY 90 billion (0.2% of GDP), to up to JPY 12 trillion yen and JPY 180 billion, respectively;
  • Setting an additional purchase limit of JPY 2 trillion (0.4% of GDP) for CP and corporate bonds, with which the Bank increases the asset purchases through September;
  • Introducing a special operation to provide interest-rate free loans putting up corporate loans as collateral.

quarantines: Special quarantine procedures are applied to all travelers regardless of nationality arriving Korea since 17 March. Quarntine measures include temperature checks, filing out health declarations at airport and downloading a self-check application to report any changes in health.
travel_Bans: Daegu and the neighboring region, severely infected area, designated as special management zone.
schools_closure: New semester (schools, kindergartens), which were supposed to start on 2 March, post-poned until 6 April.
public_events_cancel: The government operates consultative groups to respond to community infection in the large cities and region and to support information sharing. The government has also recommended people not to held public events.
Health: Mass public testing including COVID-19 drive-through test stations and smartphone apps to monitor patients. More than 260 000 people has been tested as of 16 March.
Overall_fiscal_measures: Approx. USD 10 bn (0.6% of GDP) supplementary budget  was submitted to National Assembly on 4 March.
Fiscal_firm:
Support SMEs by relaxing financial constants and by encouraging brick-and-mortar shops to open their business online
Commercial banks introduced support packages that include emergency loans to help SMEs
ax stimulus measures to stimulate demand and assist domestic businesses:
  • An increased tax deduction will be granted to individuals for the use of debit cards (from 30% to 60%) and credit cards (from 15% to 30%) for the period from March to June 2020.
  • Consumers replacing their vehicles that are at least 10 years old will be eligible for an additional 70% reduction on the consumption tax imposed.
  • VAT payable by small businesses with less than KRW 60 million in annual sales will be reduced until the end of 2021.
  • Small businesses are granted up to a 9-month extension for filing of the tax return, and up to 1 year extension for filing and paying local taxes.
Monetary_Prudential: The Bank of Korea decided to lower 50 basis points to 0.75 percent on 16 March.

quarantines: Travellers from risk countries have to undego quarantine for two weeks upon arrival.
travel_Bans: Travelling to and from coronavirus risk zones is banned.  As from 16  March, the borders with Poland and Latvia are closed (exceptions apply to foreign nationals working and permanently living in Lithuania and diplomatic staff and NATO personnel).
schools_closure: All kindergartens, schools and universities are closed for two weeks.
public_events_cancel:
All the events in both open and closed areas are prohibited throughout Lithuania. Only events limited to 100 people are allowed in open space.
All shops are closed (with the exemption of supermarkets and pharmacies).
Health: Healthcare: EUR 1.7 million from reserves granted to purchase protective gear and laboratory equipment.
Overall_fiscal_measures: The government endorsed an economic stimulus plan of EUR 2.5 billion. Measures include postponement of the payments date of tax arrears for the affected taxpayers and subsidies to preserve jobs

quarantines: n/a
travel_Bans: none
schools_closure: All schools will shut down on Monday and remain closed until 27 March. It possible that this time period will be extended depending on future developments
public_events_cancel: All events taking place inside and attracting more than 100 people are cancelled
Health: Only people displaying alarming symptoms or complications will be tested for the virus to prevent supply shortages

travel_Bans: The borders will be closed for all non-residents (starting March 17)
schools_closure: Starting March 13, the government closed all educational institutions until 14 April
public_events_cancel: Starting 13 March, all gatherings of above 50 people are prohibited
Overall_fiscal_measures: the prime minister announced (March 13) a one billion-euro (about 3.3% of GDP) fund to assist businesses through the state-owned development bank. The assistance will take various forms, from paying for sick leave, import and export guarantees and tax holidays.
Fiscal_firm: the prime minister announced (March 13) a one billion-euro (about 3.3% of GDP) fund to assist businesses through the state-owned development bank. The assistance will take various forms, from paying for sick leave, import and export guarantees and tax holidays.

quarantines: Travellers from the EU have to undergo quarantine upon arrival
schools_closure: Closure of schools and universities for one month
public_events_cancel: Mexico city is considering the cancellation of Easter week events.
Health: Mexico city has announced significant increase in measures to improve hygienic conditions in public transportation. This will be financed by reallocating from other areas not considered essential at this stage (e.g. paving roads).
Overall_fiscal_measures:
The following measures have been prepared and announced (but not yet implemented):
  • Special credit lines within the Development Banking system, aimed at providing temporary liquidity.
  • The National Banking and Securities Commission (CNBV) is working on the adoption of accounting criteria that facilitate the maintenance of credit lines.
  • The federal government will speed up pending payments and clearance of debts with suppliers, contractors and individuals, as a way to provide additional liquidity to government suppliers.
Monetary_Prudential:
Foreign exchange auctions have been made to try to stabilise the national currency
The central bank has also expressed readiness for exceptional and urgent additional measures.

quarantines: Nursing homes
travel_Bans:
EU-wide temporary restriction on non-essential travel to the EU from 16 March until at least 15 April. Ban on flights from mainland China, Hong Kong, Iran, Italy and South Korea from 13 March until at least March 27.
Health screenings on arrivals at Dutch airports. Air France-KLM announced grounding of up to 90% of its planes through April and May.
schools_closure: Schools remain closed from 16 March until 6 April. Universities were closed on 13 March. Free childcare is available for parents who work in ‘vital sectors’ such as e.g. healthcare (see list of professions: https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/cruciale-beroepsgroepen).
public_events_cancel: Ban of public events with more than 100 people from March 13 until at least 6 April. Bars, restaurants, sport clubs and coffee shops are closed until 6 April. Supermarkets remain open.
Overall_fiscal_measures: EUR 300 million for loan guarantee scheme for SMEs (BMKB)
Fiscal_people:
Subsidised reduction of working hours (werktijdverkorting)
Free childcare is available for parents who work in ‘vital sectors’ such as e.g. healthcare
Fiscal_firm:
Short-time work schemes: The number of firms applying for part-time work has risen to 2000 on 13 March. Under this scheme, employees receive unemployment benefits for a maximum of 25 weeks to compensate for reduced working hours.
Tax holiday for affected businesses (concerning corporate income tax, value added tax and payroll tax)
Temporary bridging loans for small and medium-sized enterprises (BMKB)
Implementation of shared information on the prevention and containment of the virus with SMEs

Confirmed_cases: 1169 (latest Norweigan Insitute for Public Health status report)
quarantines: No massed lockdowns as yet.
travel_Bans:
Border control measures included substantial restrictions on incoming foreigners
https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/immigration-and-integration/innsikt/questions--answers-on-new-rules-barring-entry-to-norway/id2693775/?utm_source=www.regjeringen.no&utm_medium=epost&utm_campaign=nyhetsvarsel%2017.03.2020&utm_content=Law%20and%20order
schools_closure: March 13, closure of schools announced as part of wider containment steps
public_events_cancel: March 13. Curtailment of public events/gatherings increased
Overall_fiscal_measures: March 13. The government  announces economic support measures focusing on supporting affected businesses and people.
Fiscal_people: March 13. Support for affected workers: pay of wages when companies temporarily layoff workers (detailed measures announced 13 March)
Fiscal_firm:
March 16. Two new government actions announced, adding up to NOK 100 billion in loans and guarantees to firms. https://www.regjeringen.no/no/aktuelt/100-milliarder-i-garantier-og-lan-for-a-hjelpe-kriserammede-bedrifter/id2693668/
March 18. Ministry of culture announced support for culture, sport and voluntary sectors (quoted value, NOK 900 million)
Monetary_Prudential: March 13. 50-basis-point rate cut to 1%.  Extended credit facilities to banks. Reduction in countercyclical buffer for banks

quarantines: All passengers arriving in New Zealand are assessed and screened. All arriving passengers are required to self-quarantine for 14 days.
travel_Bans: Non-NZ resident foreigners (except Australians) who have been in mainland China, Iran, or the Diamond Princess cruise ship within the last 14 days are prohibited from entering New Zealand. Cruise ships may not come to New Zealand.
public_events_cancel: Gatherings of more than 500 people are cancelled.
Health: In the context of the Covid-19 support measures announced on 17 March, NZD 500 million was allocated to the health sector.
Overall_fiscal_measures: The government announced a massive package of support measures on 17 March amounting to NZD 12.1 billion (4% of GDP), with one half to be implemented in the coming year. Most (NZD 8.7 billion) of the fiscal measures are to support businesses and jobs. There is also an NZD 2.8 billion increase in social benefit payments, which was probably brought forward from the May budget to maximise the impact of the package. The package is expected to boost GDP growth by 2 percentage points in the coming year and by further small amounts over the following two years. Even so, the NZ Treasury now projects growth of minus 1 % over the coming year, with risks to the downside. This package comes on top of the NZD 12 billion increase in infrastructure spending announced in January.
Fiscal_firm: https://www.regjeringen.no/no/aktuelt/100-milliarder-i-garantier-og-lan-for-a-hjelpe-kriserammede-bedrifter/id2693668/
Monetary_Prudential: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut the overnight cash rate by 75 basis points to 0.25% on 15 March and announced that the scheduled increase in bank capital requirements would be delayed by one year to 1 July, 2021.

quarantines: Around 8000 people are under quarantine and around 25,000 are currently under epidemiological surveillance (as of 16 March).
travel_Bans: Poland introduced full checks on its EU borders from the 15 to 24 March. Restrictions on border traffic with Russia, Ukraine and Belarus were introduced until further notice. Right to enter the country has been limited to Polish citizens and some foreign citizens, including spouses and dependants of Polish citizens, foreign citizens with temporary and permanent residence permits and work permits.
schools_closure: All schools and university closed until April 12
public_events_cancel: All gatherings of  more than 50 people prohibitted
Health: On 8 March, the authorities unlocked 23.3 million EUR (98 million PLN) for hospitals on 28 February.
Overall_fiscal_measures: On 8 March, the President signed the bill on extraordinary measures to contain the spread of coronavirus. Measures include easier conditions for remote working for persons subject to quarantine or epidemiological surveillance, care allowance for parents whose children are affected by closures of nurseries and schools, additional powers for provincial governors to take containment measures, and the possibility to suspend the application of the public procurement law and construction laws.
Fiscal_people: On March 11, The President promised additional reliefs for people having financial problems because of the coronavirus, possibly through loan rescheduling.
Fiscal_firm: The authorities are preparing measures to support the most affected firms. These will cover: subsidised loans from the state-development bank (BGK), delayed payments of social security contributions, accounting early-2020 losses as deductible from the 2019 corporate income tax payment and a suspension of public procurement penalties. After a consultation with social partners, a bill is to be presented by 20 March.
Monetary_Prudential:
At the latest Monetary Policy Council’s meeting (on 3-4 March), the Council decided to maintain the policy rate unchanged at the historically low level of 1.5%.
On 16 March, the Central Bank announced the provision of liquidity-providing repo operations to the banking system, the provision of TLTRO-type refinancing of non-financial corporate loans and large scale Treasury-bond purchases.
On 16 March, the Systemic Risk Board waived banks' contributions to the systemic risk buffer, reducing bank capital requirements.

schools_closure: Suspension of all face-to-face school activities (teaching and non-teaching) from 13th of March for a period of two weeks
public_events_cancel: Closure of nightclubs and bars while restaurants should limit their capacity by 1/3.
Health: Simplification on working overtime, hiring new employees, hiring retired doctors
Overall_fiscal_measures: On the 10th of April, the authorities unlocked EUR 296 million to increase the capacity of the health sector. Moreover, along with general public-health information, screening at airports have been introduced. All flights to Italy have been suspended until March 24th.
Fiscal_people: Postponing the payments of social security contributions and taxes, granting guaranteed treasury loans of 200 million Euros for SMEs, 60 million for micro enterprises in the tourism sector and encouraging the use of short-time work schemes (by shortening procedures and a higher public coverage of firms’ costs).

quarantines: Entry ban for all foreigners from March 18
schools_closure: All schools and university closed until April 12
Health: All gatherings of  more than 50 people prohibitted
Overall_fiscal_measures: On March 19 a number of new economic and regulatory measures will be announced, including creating an anti-crisis fund of 300 billion rubles ($4.05 billion) for support to people and the economy and compensating quarantined citizens, including freelancers and the self-employed, for lost income.
Fiscal_people: Quarantined citizens will be compensated, including freelancers and the self-employed, for lost income.
Monetary_Prudential: MinFin could sell foreign exchange reserves to stabilize the rouble

travel_Bans: all international flights are suspended for a period of two weeks, beginning on March 15
schools_closure: All schools and universities have been temporarily closed
public_events_cancel: all visits to Mecca and Medina to perform umrah and visit the Prophet’s Mosque have been suspended; all movement has been suspended into and out of the city of Qatif in the Shia-dominated Eastern Province.
Monetary_Prudential:
On Saturday 14, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority (SAMA) unveiled a SAR 50 billion (USD 13.3 billion) package:
  • SAR 30 billion available to banks and financing companies in return for deferring small and medium-size businesses’ loans for a period of six months.
  • SAR 13.2 billion in loans to SMEs provided through banks
  • SAR 6 billion loan guarantee program
  • SAR 0.8 billion to support cash-strapped retailers.

On MArch 16, SAMA cut the Repo rate by 75 basis points from 1.75% to 1.00 % and the Reverse Repo rate by 75 basis points from 1.25% to 0.50%.

quarantines: Mandatory 14-day quarantine for all people coming from abroad. For those who do not want to threaten their family members, the Interior Ministry opened its facilities.
schools_closure: The closure of schools and school facilities for 14 days, starting on March 16.
public_events_cancel:
Since 12 of March, social and cultural facilities are closed. Shopping centres are closed with only groceries, drugstores and pharmacies opened.
The closure of bars, night discos, ski centres, wellness centres and water parks. Restaurants and hotels will remain open.
The restriction of office hours in client centres, district authorities, labour offices and Sociálna Poisťovňa offices. They will be open for three hours only, while the number of clients will be limited too.
